comment.author: 57668330@N00
comment._content: According to the 6/7/17 New York Times, a Sue Spiller was one of several "gypsies" telling fortunes at a garden party held the previous afternoon on Governors Island to benefit the Army Relief Society (see "Army Fliers Give Spectators Thrills", pg. 11).

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: The other woman may be "Virginia Pritchard". She was also performing living tableaus in 1913: "Raphael's Angels Making Music, was portrayed by the Misses Virginia Pritchard, Dorothy Camp, Isabelte Yeoman, Martha Gay, Anne Brown and Janet ..." Source: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E2DD103BE633A... It looks like in 1918 she married Henry L. Hilton-Green as seen here: "Henry L. Hilton-Green, a Lieutenant in the United States Navy and Miss Virginia Pritchard, a daughter of Dr. William B. Pritchard and Mrs. Pritchard of 143 ..." Source: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F02E5D9113BEE3AB... Her papers as "Virginia Hilton-Green (1898-1993)" are archived. I will ask if the have a photograph to compare. Source: fusionmx.lib.uwf.edu/archon/?p=collections/findingaid&... For her to be the same person she would have to be 15 in 1913. She would be 19 if this was 1917 and the Army gypsies.
